===Home media=== The film was released on DVD by [[Lionsgate Home Entertainment]] on August 29, 2006, becoming the first [[DVD]] offered for sale at Starbucks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.videobusiness.com/article/CA6340569.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j7VkJQ72?url=http://www.videobusiness.com/article/CA6340569.html |title=Starbucks rocks with Berry DVD |author=Ault, Susanne |accessdate=August 18, 2009 |archivedate=August 18, 2009 |date=June 2, 2006 |work=Video Business |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] }}</ref> Its bonus features on the single-disc DVD include seven deleted scenes and a 25-minute making-of video featuring Atchinson and the cast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/reviews/?id=2054 |title=Movie Review: Akeelah and the Bee |work=Box Office Mojo |publisher=Amazon.com |author=Holleran, Scott | year=2006 |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv4bynsp?url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/reviews/?id=2054 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> DVD sales in the United States reached $5,391,947 as 317,942 copies were sold after one week on sale. By December 2006, American consumers had spent a total of $25,855,396 to purchase 1,512,498 copies,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2006/AKELA-DVD.php |title=Akeelah and the Bee – DVD Sales |work=The Numbers |publisher=Nash Information Services |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv4iEEtx?url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2006/AKELA-DVD.php |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> making it one of the three most profitable home video releases of Lionsgate in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/revenues-boost-lionsgate-q3-earnings-129908 |title=Revenues boost Lionsgate Q3 earnings |author=Vlessing, Etan | date=February 2, 2007 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=July 20, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6a9h57BvJ?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/revenues-boost-lionsgate-q3-earnings-129908 |archivedate=July 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
===Critical reaction=== [[File:Keke Palmer.jpg|thumb|Keke Palmer's portrayal of Akeelah was highly praised by critics, with one saying she "[stole the] movie from Angela Bassett and Laurence Fishburne".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?slug=akeelah28&date=20060428 |title=Akeelah and the Bee": Young star casts quite a spell in busy, busy "Bee |date=April 28, 2006 |author=Macdonald, Moira |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv8ewljI?url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?slug=akeelah28&date=20060428 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Palmer's performance led her to win several awards, including a [[Black Movie Awards|Black Movie Award]], a [[Black Reel Awards|Black Reel Award]], a [[NAACP Image Award]], and a [[Young Artist Award]].<ref name=bma/><ref name=bra/><ref name=image/><ref name=young/>]]
The film received generally positive reviews from [[film criticism|film critic]]s. The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports an 84% approval rating based on 138 reviews, with an average rating of 7.1/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "A warm, family-friendly underdog story, featuring terrific supporting performances from Keke Palmer, Laurence Fishburne, and Angela Bassett."<ref name=rt>{{cite web | url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/akeelah_and_the_bee | title = Akeelah and the Bee (2006) | accessdate=August 30, 2017 | work=Rotten Tomatoes | publisher=[[Flixster]]}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has an average weighted score of 72 out 100, based on 30 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/akeelah-and-the-bee | title=Akeelah and the Bee | publisher=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=May 10, 2014}}</ref> [[CinemaScore]] reported that audiences gave the film a rare<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=89927 |title=The Avengers Makes $80.5 Million Its Opening Day! |publisher=CraveOnline |work=ComingSoon.net |date=May 5, 2012 |accessdate=May 5, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67RRbeYXL?url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=89927 |archivedate=May 5, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> average grade of "A+".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-cinemascore-matters-box-office-225563 |title=Why CinemaScore Matters for Box Office |author=McClintock, Pamela |date=August 19, 2011 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PTUrtDVN?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-cinemascore-matters-box-office-225563 |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
[[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' wrote it is "an uncommonly good movie, entertaining and actually inspirational".<ref name=ebert>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/akeelah-and-the-bee-2006 |date=April 27, 2006 |author=Ebert, Roger |accessdate=May 16, 2011 |publisher=rogerebert.com |title=Akeelah and the Bee Review (2006) |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv5vriYG?url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/akeelah-and-the-bee-2006 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Writing for ''[[Film Journal International]]'', Doris Toumarkine praised its pace and how "Atchison takes spelling competitions and conveys the excitement of the 'sport,' the appeal of the 'game,' the thrill of the win, [and] the crushing blow of the loss."<ref name=filmj>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002383630 |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Toumarkine, Doris |date=April 20, 2006 |work=Film Journal International |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=June 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv5xIVy1?url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002383630 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Hornaday from ''The Washington Post'' called the film "a triumph on many levels" and proclaimed, "It's that nod to the collective ... that makes ''Akeelah and the Bee'' so special." She especially appreciated that South Los Angeles was presented without stereotypes.<ref name=wpost>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/27/AR2006042702373.html |title='Akeelah and the Bee': One Honey of a Flick |author=Hornaday, Ann |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Washington Post |publisher=Nash Holdings |accessdate=June 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv5wiKzS?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/27/AR2006042702373.html |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Jane Clifford of ''[[U-T San Diego]]'' felt the film would appeal to both children and adults, and stated that every time she tried to predict its plot "it took a sharp turn. A turn that leaves you facing your stereotypes and feeling a little sheepish."<ref name=utsd>{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060429/news_1c29clifford.html |title='Akeelah' a letter-perfect feel-good family film |author=Clifford, Jane |date=April 29, 2006 |work=U-T San Diego |publisher=[[Copley Newspapers]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv6QrfgZ?url=http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060429/news_1c29clifford.html |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> [[Dana Stevens (critic)|Dana Stevens]], writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', asserted, "The innate suspense and charm of the spelling bee," and "a trio of crack performances" can turn "a formulaic sports picture" into a "tale that manages to inspire without being sappy."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies2.nytimes.com/2006/04/28/movies/28akee.html |title=A Young Girl and Big Words in 'Akeelah and the Bee' |author=Stevens, Dana |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7519ZX?url=http://movies2.nytimes.com/2006/04/28/movies/28akee.html |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Shantayaé Grant of ''[[The Jamaica Observer]]'' wrote that "acting is spectacular, the emotions are real and this story of black triumph is simply phenomenal."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/teenage/Black-History-in-Movies_13545736 |title=Black History in Movies |date=February 5, 2013 |work=The Jamaica Observer |accessdate=August 2, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130214000934/http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/teenage/Black-History-in-Movies_13545736 |archivedate=February 14, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ''New York Press'' critic affirmed that ''Akeelah and the Bee'' "resurrects a nearly lost idea of what an art-movie really is" because it has "dramatic attention to character and place, psychology and existence."<ref name=nypress/>
Chang of ''Variety'' commented that it "plays like ''[[The Karate Kid]]'' with a pro-literacy agenda, pushing all the right emotional buttons yet hitting quite a few wrong ones in the process."<ref name=chang/> The ''[[Evening Chronicle]]''{{'}}s review said it "conceals few narrative surprises" but contended that "when [Atchison] does finally defy our expectations, it's to ensure his spellers learn a valuable lesson about integrity."<ref name=chronicle>{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/film-tv/akeelah-and-the-bee-1545750 |title=Akeelah and the Bee |date=August 18, 2006 |work=Evening Chronicle |accessdate=June 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv6LUmqF?url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/film-tv/akeelah-and-the-bee-1545750 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Turan of the ''Los Angeles Times'' criticized that the film "telegraphs its plot"; however, he praised it as "genuinely sweet and determinedly inspirational."<ref name=turan>{{cite web|url=http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/turan/cl-et-akeelah28apr28,0,6385780.story |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060829024947/http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/turan/cl-et-akeelah28apr28%2C0%2C6385780.story |archivedate=August 29, 2006 |title=Movie Review - 'Akeelah and the Bee' |date=April 28, 2006 |author=Turan, Kenneth |work=Los Angeles Times |publisher=Tribune Publishing |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ''[[PopMatters]]''{{'}}s Cynthia Fuchs stated it is formulaic as it has some "conventions that make so many other genre films feel stale," but that it "torques them slightly", emphasizing the "intellectual activities" Akeelah gets involved with.<ref name=fuchs>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/akeelah_and_the_bee_2006/ |title=Akeelah and the Bee (2006) |author=Fuchs, Cynthia |date=April 28, 2006 |work=PopMatters |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv6P7c2g?url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/akeelah_and_the_bee_2006/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Furthermore, the film was described as "derivatively entertaining in a feel-good sort of way" by Rick Groen in an article for ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=https://www.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FLAC.20060428.BEE28%2FTPStory%2FTPEntertainment%2F&ord=14321757&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080204080758/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FLAC.20060428.BEE28%2FTPStory%2FTPEntertainment%2F&ord=14321757&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true |archivedate=February 4, 2008 |title=A star shines in a bee movie |author=Groen, Rick |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Globe and Mail |publisher=[[CTVglobemedia]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Ingman of ''The Austin Chronicle'' described it as a typical sports film and felt it was heavy-handed at times. However, she praised it for its themes and called the film a "[t]houghtful, engaging," one and said it has "cross-gender appeal".<ref name=austinc>{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/calendar/film/2006-04-28/360512/ |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Ingman, Marrit |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Austin Chronicle |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv6oSl2Q?url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/calendar/film/2006-04-28/360512/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Morris of ''The Boston Globe'' argued, "If ''Akeelah and the Bee'' is a generic, well-oiled commercial contraption, it is the first to credibly dramatize the plight of a truly gifted, poor black child." Morris added, "Obviously, it's emotional propaganda. But it's just the kind of propaganda our children need."<ref name=morris>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2006/04/28/in_a_word_akeelah_spells_crowd_pleaser/ |title=In a word, 'Akeelah' spells crowd-pleaser |author=Morris, Wesley |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Boston Globe |publisher=Boston Globe Media Partners |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv79ILgK?url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2006/04/28/in_a_word_akeelah_spells_crowd_pleaser/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Despite being a "critically acclaimed" film, according to Rotten Tomatoes,<ref name=rt/> not all of its reviews were this positive. Anna Smith of ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' called it "formulaic and all-American", commenting that many scenes "appear functional rather than inspirational", and that the film focused on the racial issue "a little too heavily". Smith stated, "clunky plotting and characterisation mean it has 'telemovie' written all over it."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=134416 |title=Akeelah And The Bee Review |author=Smith, Anna |date=March 26, 2007 |work=Empire |publisher=[[Bauer Media Group]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7Vf6h1?url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=134416 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Marc Mohan from ''[[The Oregonian]]'' stressed it can be compared to [[after-school special]]s due to its "lack of originality in plot and character."<ref name=oregon>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/entertainment/1146088530229920.xml&coll=7 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070111214847/http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/oregonian/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fentertainment%2F1146088530229920.xml&coll=7 |title=Akeelah and the B movie |archivedate=January 11, 2007 |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Oregonian |author=Mohan, Marc |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]''{{'}}s Jessica Winter also drew a comparation to after-school specials, saying "on the big screen ... its clichés seem bigger and its characterisations broader than they would on the more forgiving telly."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/akeelah-and-the-bee |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Winter, Jessica |date=August 17, 2006 |work=Time Out |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7YTNFy?url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/akeelah-and-the-bee |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Nick Schager of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' lamented that the "clichés are too numerous to mention",<ref name=slant>{{cite web | url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/Film/film_review.asp?ID=2164 | title=Film Review: Akeelah and the Bee | author=Schager, Nick | work=Slant Magazine | date=April 21, 2006 | accessdate=June 21, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804075926/http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/film_review.asp?ID=2164 | archivedate=August 4, 2007}}</ref> while Neil Smith from [[BBC]] asserted it has "as much ... fantasy as ''[[Lord of the Rings]]''."<ref name=bbc>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2006/08/09/akeelah_and_the_bee_2006_review.shtml |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Smith, Neil |date=August 14, 2006 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7uuhQQ?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2006/08/09/akeelah_and_the_bee_2006_review.shtml |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Jan Stuart of ''[[Newsday]]'' deemed it "virtually suspense-free,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/movies/ny-etmovie4718457apr28,0,5719140.story?coll=ny-moviereview-headlines |title=Sting of defeat for 'Bee' is the plot |author=Stuart, Jan |date=April 28, 2006 |work=Newsday |publisher=[[Cablevision]] |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327231715/http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/movies/ny-etmovie4718457apr28%2C0%2C5719140.story?coll=ny-moviereview-headlines |archivedate=2008-03-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> while Robert Hanks of ''[[The Independent]]'' stated it has an important message but that is a "shame it couldn't be encased in a less faked-up story".<ref name=independent>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/akeelah-and-the-bee-12a--none-onestar-twostar-threestar-fourstar-fivestar-412273.html |title=Akeelah and the Bee (12A) |author=Hanks, Robert |date=August 18, 2006 |work=The Independent |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aT5Y7rZa?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/akeelah-and-the-bee-12a--none-onestar-twostar-threestar-fourstar-fivestar-412273.html |archivedate=August 1, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Commenting on ''[[The Times]]'', [[Chris Ayres]] stressed that although it has good "visual flair" it "is ruined by its ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show|Oprah]]''-style [[emotional manipulation]]."<ref>{{cite news | title=A spell of good fortune | author=Ayres, Chris | work=The Times | date=August 17, 2006 | publisher=[[News UK]] | pages=18–19 (''Times2'' supplement)}}</ref> ''[[New York Post]]''{{'}}s [[Kyle Smith]] deemed it as "uplifting but unimaginative", suggesting that "''Akeelah and the Bee'' is so warm and well-meaning that you may find yourself wanting to like it more than you really do."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2006/04/28/spelling-error/ |title=Spelling Error |last=Smith |first=Kyle |date=April 28, 2006 |work=New York Post |publisher=[[News Corp]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7vh9Eb?url=http://nypost.com/2006/04/28/spelling-error/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
In spite of criticism, cast members' performances were usually well received – in particular, Palmer's portrayal of Akeelah. Ebert said, "The movie depends on her, and she deserves its trust."<ref name=ebert/> Hornaday opined that "Palmer's Akeelah is that cinematic ''[[wikt:rara avis|rara avis]]'', the kid who is cute without being too cute, sympathetic without being cloying, and believable without being tiresome."<ref name=wpost/> ''Evening Chronicle'' stated Palmer does it "with effortless grace" and that she "carries the film and doesn't strike a single wrong emotional note."<ref name=chronicle/> Fuchs felt that most of the film's strengths "have to do with Palmer's winning performance."<ref name=fuchs/> Ingman declared Atchison's "ensemble is wonderful, and his star, Palmer, is a fantastically assured young actress who conveys Akeelah's maelstrom of 11-year-old feelings with no apparent effort."<ref name=austinc/> Turan complimented how Fishburne and Bassett's "presence and ability give this film a welcome integrity."<ref name=turan/> Mohan stated, "Although Fishburne and Bassett can do these roles in their sleep, the kids are actually quite engaging."<ref name=oregon/> Tourmakine felt there were "fine performances all around" and that Fishburne and Bassett "lend fine support in utterly believable roles".<ref name=filmj/>
====Racial issues==== Chang called Dylan's father "a stiff Asian stereotype",<ref name=chang/> while Mohan of ''The Oregonian'' found it contradictory for an anti-racist film to contain such depiction.<ref name=oregon/> [[Peter Bradshaw]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' even claimed that the line "If you can barely beat a little black girl" (spoken by Dylan's father) signifies that Atchison "thinks it's all right to bring in racism by making the Asians the racists."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/aug/18/drama.family |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Bradshaw, Peter |work=The Guardian |date=August 18, 2006 |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7Z4BoP?url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/aug/18/drama.family |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ''[[Metro Silicon Valley]]''{{'}}s Richard von Busack commented that "[s]tepping around black stereotypes, the film squishes its two left feet right in the mire of Asian stereotyping."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroactive.com/metro/04.26.06/akeelah-0617.html |title=Casting a Spell |author=von Busack, Richard |date=April 26, 2006 |work=Metro Silicon Valley |publisher=[[Metro Newspapers]] |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aT67Wcg7?url=http://www.metroactive.com/metro/04.26.06/akeelah-0617.html |archivedate=August 1, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Beth Accomando of [[KPBS (TV)|KPBS]] also criticized Dylan and his father's portrayal as "painful cliches",<ref name=kpbs/> while Schager of ''Slant Magazine'' found it not authentic, even likening Dylan's father to [[Mao Zedong]].<ref name=slant/>
Scholars Charise Pimentel and Cathleen Sawyer from the [[Texas State University]] published an article titled "''Akeelah and the Bee'': Inspirational Story of African-American Intellect and Triumph or Racist Rhetoric Served Up On Another Platter?" on the May 2011 issue of journal ''Multicultural Perspectives''.{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=100}} On a [[critical discourse analysis]], the authors argue that despite appearing to be an "inoccent enough" film, it has major approaches that make it racist.{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=100}} First, it implies that African-Americans needs to be rescued by others;{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=100}} second, depicts African-Americans community as "marked by homelessness, poverty, criminality, unemployment, and remnants of gang activity";{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=101}} third, indicates that black people usually only achieve success through sports by "linking the very essence of Akeelah's phenomenal ability to spell to her rhythmic abilities";{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=103}} and shows that African-Americans only can succeed outside their communities, "far from the oppressive clutches of their own."{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=104}}
Linder, on her September 2011 paper "Spelling Out Racial Difference: Moving Beyond the Inspirational Discourses in ''Akeelah and the Bee''", also criticizes it saying it "acts as a platform for a racial melodrama through which ideals of whiteness are reinforced and strengthened."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=19}} Using [[Linda Williams (film scholar)|Linda Williams]]' categories of what constitutes a racial [[melodrama]], Linder argues that it is described as an "inspirational" film because of "[its] portrayal of Akeelah's victimization by the black community that surrounds her" and of redemption only achieved "through the idealized discourse of young people's educational success as defined by dominant (white) culture."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=22}} Linder said characters "are mostly represented as having 'no interest in escape' from societal oppressions and limitations" and that "there is no sign throughout the film of any kind of lasting change for Akeelah's school or her young peers."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=30}}
Linder affirms that it creates a dichotomy between "success (whiteness) versus failure (blackness)."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=30}} Pimentel and Sawyer, as well as Linder, identify Larabee as the one who makes this separation clear when he manifests his disregard of [[African American Vernacular English]].{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=26}}{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=101}} The co-authors wrote that Larabee implies that "legitimate forms of intelligence can only be achieved through a Eurocentric perspective, thus advancing the message that Akeelah must be rescued from her African-American ways of knowing, in order to be considered intellectual."{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=101}} Another contraposition commented by scholars was "between the supportive Dr. Larabee and Akeelah's skeptical mother."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=28}} Pimental and Sawyer said she is portrayed as "an African-American obstructionist",{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=103-104}} while scholar Gloria Ladson‐Billings asserted she represents the stereotype of "ignorant Black woman".{{sfn|Ladson‐Billings|2009|p=93}} Although Fuchs said the film was able to avoid the "[[white savior narrative in film|white authority figure saves the underclass child]]" plotline by introducing Larabee,<ref name=fuchs/> Ladson‐Billings, Linder, and Pimentel and Sawyer opined that it did not.{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=103-104}}{{sfn|Ladson‐Billings|2009|p=93}} After all, Larabee, as Linder described, is "a non-threatening black man who has assimilated to white culture and who can be depended on to help assimilate others".{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=30}}
===Accolades=== The film was nominated for six [[Black Reel Awards]], winning only Best Actress for Palmer.<ref name=bra/><ref name=bra2/> Out of five [[NAACP Image Award]]s nominations, ''Akeelah and the Bee'' won Outstanding Actress in a Motion Picture and Outstanding Writing in a Feature Film/Television Movie - Comedy or Drama.<ref name=image/><ref name=image2/> At the [[Black Movie Awards]], it won the five awards it was nominated for.<ref name=bma/> The same happened during the [[Young Artist Awards]] where it was nominated for two categories and won two awards,<ref name=young/> and at the [[CAMIE Awards]] where it was nominated for and won an award.<ref name=camie/> The film was also nominated for but did not win any award from the [[BET Awards]],<ref name=bet/><ref name=bet2/> [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards]],<ref name=bfca/> [[Chicago Film Critics]],<ref name=cfc/><ref name=cfc2/> and [[Satellite Awards]].<ref name=sat/><ref name=sat2/> [[National Board of Review]] elected it among the best ten independent films produced in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/board-review-votes-iwo-jima-145666 |title=Board of Review votes 'Iwo Jima' best picture |author=Goldstein, Gregg |work=The Hollywood Reporter |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=July 20, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6a9gh2DR4?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/board-review-votes-iwo-jima-145666 |archivedate=July 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Additionally, two film critics, Chris Kaltenbach of ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'' and Carrie Rickey of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', added the film on their list of the ten best films of the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2006-12-29/features/0612290186_1_controversial-films-lenfant-film-ends |title=Chris Kaltenbach's Favorite Films |author=Kaltenbach, Chris |date=December 29, 2006 |work=The Baltimore Sun |publisher=Tribune Publishing |accessdate=May 23, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YkHBIS9l?url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2006-12-29/features/0612290186_1_controversial-films-lenfant-film-ends |archivedate=May 23, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/2006-12-31/entertainment/25398368_1_great-performances-akeelah-actress-categories |title=2006 The Year on Screen - As performers reclaimed the movies, give them an A for acting |author=Rickey, Carrie |date=December 31, 2006 |work=The Philadelphia Inquirer |publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network]] |accessdate=May 23, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YkHECiOq?url=http://articles.philly.com/2006-12-31/entertainment/25398368_1_great-performances-akeelah-actress-categories |archivedate=May 23, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]''{{'}}s Steve Persall elected it the best family film of 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/12/29/Floridian/For_fans__a_happy_end.shtml |title=For fans, a happy ending after all |author=Persall, Steve |date=December 29, 2006 |work=St. Petersburg Times |publisher=[[Times Publishing Company]] |accessdate=July 26, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aJuKWqT6?url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/12/29/Floridian/For_fans__a_happy_end.shtml |archivedate=July 26, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} An '''art blog''' is a common type of [[blog]] that comments on art. More recently, as with other types of blogs, some art blogs have taken on 'web 2.0' social networking features. Art blogs that adopt this sort of change can develop to become a source of information on art events (listings and maps), a way to share information and images, or virtual meeting ground. Art blogs entries cover different topics, from art critiques and commentary to insider art world gossip, auction results, art news, personal essays, portfolios, interviews, artists’ journals, art marketing advice and artist biographies. Some artists use art blogs as a form of new media art project. Art blogs may also serve as a forum to reach out to anybody interested in art — be it painting, sculpture, print making, creative photography, video art, conceptual art or new media. In this way, they may be visited not only for the practitioners of different forms of art, but also collectors, connoisseurs, and critics. ==Mainstream media== In 2011, art critic [[Brian Sherwin]] interviewed art critic Mat Gleason of [[Coagula Art Journal]] for Faso.com's FineArtViews blog. The interview between Sherwin and Gleason focused on [[contemporary art]] criticism and the role of art blog’s in present-day [[art criticism]] among other issues. Gleason suggested to Sherwin that art blogs and the development of new media have become a "''blow''" to traditional print art magazines. Gleason and Sherwin also discussed how [[bloggers]] form a "''pack mentality''" based on region and perceived significance.[http://faso.com/fineartviews/27987/fineartviews-interview-mat-gleason-art-critic-and-founder-of-coagula-art-journal "FineArtViews Interview: Mat Gleason -- Art Critic and Founder of Coagula Art Journal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111218141116/http://faso.com/fineartviews/27987/fineartviews-interview-mat-gleason-art-critic-and-founder-of-coagula-art-journal |date=18 December 2011 }}, Faso.com - FineArtViews. Retrieved 7 January 2012.[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/26/fineartsviews-interviews-_n_828719.html "FineArtViews Interviews Mat Gleason, Art Critic/Founder of Coagula"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420061624/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/26/fineartsviews-interviews-_n_828719.html |date=20 April 2012 }}, Huffington Post. Retrieved 7 January 2012. On April 28, 2009, Art Connect produced an in-depth interview by Peter Cowling for [[Art Connect]] and Jessica Palmer of [[Bioephemera]]. The interview, titled It is not Really Bloggers vs. Journalists, You Know,Cowling, Peter and Palmer, Jessica, "It is not Really Bloggers vs. Journalists, You Know", April 2009 {{cite web|url=http://www.loveart-gallery.com/art-blog-reviews/2009/04/27/extraordinary-art-blogs-series-part-seven-it-is-not-really-bloggers-vs-journalists-you-know |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701133911/http://www.loveart-gallery.com/art-blog-reviews/2009/04/27/extraordinary-art-blogs-series-part-seven-it-is-not-really-bloggers-vs-journalists-you-know/ |archivedate=1 July 2009 |df=dmy }} pointed to five trends that were shaping the communication and discussion of art on the internet, and that the real picture was much bigger than just the bloggers vs. journalists that had been discussed to date. These five points were: * Media convergence will continue to improve consumer choice, providing a better match between desire and availability. * Content producers are just that. Consumers care less about how and where they can get the content they want. What they do consistently care about is the quality of the content, and whether the content is produced to their timescales. * The content producer-to-content consumer relationship is changing. Requests for feedback and further debate have been partially overtaken by things like conversations, and further fragmentation will certainly occur. * Information technology and systems, provided as commodity (pay-as-you-go) services. Such services range from processing and storage, through to credit card processing and super-fast content delivery. * The economic downrun. On January 8, 2009, Regina Hackett, art critic of the [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]], noted in her article Art Blogs Hit Wikipedia Hackett, Regina, "Art Blogs Hit Wikipedia." ''Seattle Post-Intelligencer'', January 2009. {{cite web |url=http://blog.seattlepi.nwsource.com/art/archives/159041.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-19 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720231949/http://blog.seattlepi.nwsource.com/art/archives/159041.asp |archivedate=20 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} that commercially run, mainstream media supported, art blogs face issues of acceptance among the independent art blogging community. On January 7, 2009, ''[[The Village Voice]]'' art critic Martha Schwendener suggests that art blogs have helped shape a more laissez-faire climate for art writing. "Art blogs have created a new, largely unedited, admirably 'unprofessional'—hence, democratic—venue for people to speak their minds, gossip, or theorize about art."Schwendener, Martha, "What Crisis? Some Promising Futures for Art Criticism." ''The Village Voice'', January 2009. {{cite web |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2009-01-07/art/what-crisis-some-promising-futures-for-art-criticism/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116123956/http://www.villagevoice.com/2009-01-07/art/what-crisis-some-promising-futures-for-art-criticism |archivedate=16 January 2009 |df=dmy-all }} In September 2008, the ''[[Brooklyn Rail]]'' contributor [[James Kalm]] produced an article titled "Virtually Overwhelmed.".[http://www.brooklynrail.org/2008/09/artseen/brooklyn-dispatches-virtually-overwhelmed Kalm, James, "Virtually Overwhelmed." ''Brooklyn Rail''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105114244/http://www.brooklynrail.org/2008/09/artseen/brooklyn-dispatches-virtually-overwhelmed |date=5 January 2009 }} A practicing artist and video blogger himself, Kalm has this to say about art blogs, "The art blogosphere is a work in progress, and you’ve got to be vigilant of hidden agendas. As with anything online, take it with a grain of salt. Have fun, speak out, but don’t let it cut too much into your studio time; you might end up in a twelve step-program." In the November 2007 issue of ''[[Art in America]]'', [[Peter Plagens]] contributed "Report from the Blogosphere: The New Grass Roots."Plagens, Peter, "Report from the Blogosphere: The New Grass Roots." ''Art in America'', November 2007. [http://madsilence.wordpress.com/2008/02/03/the-future-of-the-art-blog/] Plagens convened a round table of veteran art bloggers, who conversed via email on a range of questions, aimed at getting a better understanding of what art blogs were, how they were run, and their relationship with the mainstream media. In an October 2007 article for artnet Magazine, critic Charlie Finch suggested that art critiques and reviews by art bloggers are overrated and lengthy, and implied that the art blogging community was overly insular.Finch, Charlie, "A NOT-SO-VAST RIGHT-WING CONSPIRACY" ''artnet Magazine'', {{cite web |url=http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/finch/finch10-26-07.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418041306/http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/finch/finch10-26-07.asp |archivedate=18 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} The article includes several ''ad hominen'' arguments against specific art bloggers, and ventures the opinion that art blogs "have no readers". In the January 2005 issue of ''[[Art in America]]'',Rubinstein, Rafael, "Art in the Blogoshere." ''Art in America'', "Front Page," January 2005. {{cite web |url=http://www.firstpulseprojects.com/frontpageaia.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080807172818/http://www.firstpulseprojects.com/frontpageaia.pdf |archivedate=7 August 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Raphael Rubinstein mentioned several blogs in the magazine's "Front Page" section, where he penned a brief, annotated survey of 12 art blogs that he found "to be worth regular visits.". Rubinstein opined that "art-related blogs" had not, at the time, become as consequential as blogs in other fields such as poetry or politics. == Academia == In December 2008, the art blog [[Maurice Benayoun|The Dump]],{{cite web|url=http://www.the-dump.net/|title=The-dump|author=|date=|website=www.the-dump.net|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180212143100/http://the-dump.net/|archivedate=12 February 2018|df=dmy-all}} where the new-media artist [[Maurice Benayoun]] dumped hundreds of undone art projects, was the first to become a doctorate thesis in art and art science in and of itself: ''Artistic Intentions at Work, Hypothesis for Committing Art'' Université Pantheon Sorbonne (December 6, 2008) This PhD was directed by Prof. Anne-Marie Duguet. Jury : Prof. [[Hubertus von Amelunxen]], [[Louis Bec]], artist, Prof. [[Derrick de Kerckhove]], and Prof. Jean da Silva.
In May 2010, ''The Dump – Recycling of Thoughts'', a contemporary art exhibition curated by Agnieszka Kulazińska at Laznia Art Center ([[Gdańsk]], [[Poland]]) presented 9 artists whose works were derived from ''The Dump'' blog project list.{{cite web|url=http://www.laznia.pl/index.php?idDzial=9&idWpis=525|title=Centrum Sztuki Współczesnej Łaźnia|first=Studio eMart|last=biuro@studioemart.pl|date=|website=www.laznia.pl|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314081644/http://laznia.pl/index.php?iddzial=9&idwpis=525|archivedate=14 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} ==Other coverage == Other coverage of art blogs includes interviews of art bloggers, reviews of art blog site, and recommendations of favourite sites. Art Connect has produced around 90 reviews of art blogs, and undertakes interviews with art bloggers.[http://www.loveart-gallery.com/art-blog-reviews/ Art Connect review of art blogs] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124135259/http://www.loveart-gallery.com/art-blog-reviews/ |date=24 January 2009 }} The [[Courtauld Institute of Art]], in London, maintains a list of recommended art blogs .List of art blogs recommended by the Courtauld Institute of Art, London, {{cite web |url=http://www.courtauld.ac.uk/booklibrary/collections_services/links.shtml/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029201701/http://www.courtauld.ac.uk/booklibrary/collections_services/links.shtml |archivedate=29 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Directories such as Yahoo! Directory and BlogCatalog maintain a list of user submitted art blogs. ==List of notable art blogs== *''[[Mira Schor|A Year of Positive Thinking]]'' {{cite web|url=http://ayearofpositivethinking.com/|title=A Year of Positive Thinking - Mira Schor|author=|date=|website=ayearofpositivethinking.com|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707202156/http://ayearofpositivethinking.com/ |archivedate=7 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} is published by artist and activist [[Mira Schor]], "a cheerful postscript" to her book of essays on art, culture and politics called ''A Decade of Negative Thinking''. *''[[Paddy Johnson|Art F City]]'" founded by Paddy Johnson, this officially non-profit art blog covers new art in New York. At the NYTimes, Holland Cotter named AFC as a blog that "combines criticism, reporting, political activism and gossip on an almost-24-hour news cycle."Holland Cotter,"Lost in the Gallery-Industrial Complex," New York Times, January 17, 2014.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/19/arts/design/holland-cotter-looks-at-money-in-art.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-02-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729010753/https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/19/arts/design/holland-cotter-looks-at-money-in-art.html |archivedate=29 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} *''[[Maurice Benayoun|The Dump]]'' by the French new media artist [[Maurice Benayoun]] delivering hundreds of undone art projects [http://www.cgw.com/Print.aspx?Page=/Publications/CGW/2009/Volume-32-Issue-4-Apr-2009-/Without-Bounds.aspx] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716201324/http://www.cgw.com/Print.aspx?Page=%2FPublications%2FCGW%2F2009%2FVolume-32-Issue-4-Apr-2009-%2FWithout-Bounds.aspx |date=16 July 2011 }} ''Without Bounds'' by Barbara Robertson in CGW volume 32 issue 4 April 2009 * ''[[Hyperallergic]]'', founded by the art critic Hrag Vartanian and his husband Veken Gueyikian in October 2009. The site describes itself as a "forum for serious, playful and radical thinking."{{cite web|url=http://hyperallergic.com/|title=Hyperallergic|author=|date=|website=Hyperallergic|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323204905/https://hyperallergic.com/|archivedate=23 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} *''[[NEWSgrist]]'',{{cite web|url=http://newsgrist.typepad.com/|title=NEWSgrist - where spin is art|author=|date=|website=newsgrist.typepad.com|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323152450/http://newsgrist.typepad.com/|archivedate=23 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} maintained by artist [[Joy Garnett]], began in March 2000 as an e-zine devoted to the politics of art and culture in the digital age. For four years it was distributed entirely by email subscription. *''[[PORT]]'', co-founded in 2005 by Jennifer Armbrust and [[Jeff Jahn]] (who still maintains the site) PORT{{cite web|url=http://www.portlandart.net/|title=PORT: portlandart.net - Portland art + news + reviews|author=|date=|website=www.portlandart.net|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171121025150/http://www.portlandart.net/|archivedate=21 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} focuses on critical content related to the Portland art scene. PORT describes itself as "dedicated to catalyzing critical discussion and disseminating information about art as lensed through Portland, Oregon." In the November 2007 Art in America roundtable Plagens described PORT as, "the closest thing to the virtues (paid critics, office help, etc.) of a print art magazine on the Internet...." In 2007 [[Tyler Green (journalist)|Tyler Green]] described PORT as, "The undisputed champ of the regional art blogs." on Off Center, the Walker Art Center's blog. *''The Silo''{{cite web|url=http://thesilo.raphaelrubinstein.com/|title=The Silo by Raphael Rubinstein|author=|date=|website=thesilo.raphaelrubinstein.com|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322094709/http://thesilo.raphaelrubinstein.com/|archivedate=22 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} is maintained by art critic and poet Raphael Rubinstein. A revisionist “dictionary” of contemporary art aimed at challenging existing accounts of art since 1960 and to offer a fresh look at some well-known artists, The Silo was originally funded by an Andy Warhol/Creative Capital Arts Writing Grant. *''[[Two Coats of Paint]],''[http://www.twocoatsofpaint.com/ Two Coats of Paint] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140705141241/http://www.twocoatsofpaint.com/ |date=5 July 2014 }} founded by Sharon Butler in 2007, is dedicated to contemporary painting and related subjects. Received a Creative Capital/Warhol Foundation Arts Writing Grant in 2013-14. *''[[Fruit Carving Art Blog]],''{{cite web|url=http://www.fruitcarvinglessons.co.uk/|title=Fruit Carving Lessons - Fruit Carving Classes - Vegetable Carving - FruitCarvingLessons.co.uk|author=|date=|website=www.fruitcarvinglessons.co.uk|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171014172335/http://www.fruitcarvinglessons.co.uk/|archivedate=14 October 2017|df=dmy-all}} founded by Kelly in 2007 *''[[Wooster Collective]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.woostercollective.com/|title=Wooster Collective|author=|date=|website=Wooster Collective|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151027052728/http://woostercollective.com/|archivedate=27 October 2015|df=dmy-all}} was founded in 2001. This site focuses on ephemeral art placed on streets in cities around the world. Updated by Marc and Sara Schiller, the site also offers podcasting with music and interviews featuring street artists. *''[[In Terms Of]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.in-terms-of.com/|title=In Terms Of|author=|date=|website=In Terms Of|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171221010952/http://www.in-terms-of.com/|archivedate=21 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}, created by the art critic and historian Christopher Howard, first came online in 2011. The site publishes reviews of lectures, panels, interviews, conferences, and other live speaking engagements in the visual arts. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Art blogs}} {{Blog topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Art Blog}} [[Category:Blogs by subject]] [[Category:Blogospheres]] [[Category:Art websites]]

page.title: Artistic depictions of the Bangladesh Liberation War

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} [[Image:Jatiyo Smriti Soudho, concrete modernist monument and memorial gardens, at Savar near Dakar in central Bangladesh.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Bangladesh's national monument, [[Jatiyo Smriti Soudho]], located in Savar, [[Dhaka]], is a tribute to the martyrs of the Liberation War]] {{Culture of Bangladesh}}
There has been numerous works of art that depicted the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]] during and since the War both at Bangladesh and abroad. The concert for Bangladesh organized by members of the Beatles was a major happening in 1971 for protest music. The songs recorded for and broadcast on [[Swadhin Bangla Betar Kendra]] are still considered to be the best of Bangladeshi protest songs.
The four documentaries made during the War – [[Zahir Raihan]]'s ''[[Stop Genocide]]'' and ''A State Is Born'', Babul Chowdhry's ''Innocent Millions'', Alamgir Kabir's ''Liberation Fighters'' – are described as the first films made in [[Bangladesh]], as earlier films were all made in Pakistan or India, larger entities that Bangladesh belonged to. ''[[Muktir Gaan]] (Song of Freedom)'', based on footage shot by Leer Levin during the war, by [[Tareque Masud|Tareque]] and Kathrine Masud is critically the most acclaimed Bangladeshi documentary. The directors followed the film with two sequels – ''[[Muktir Kotha|Story of Freedom]]'' and ''Narir Katha''. Their feature film on the same subject, ''[[Matir Moyna]]'', won the FIPRESCII award at Cannes Film Festival.
There have been numerous poems and novels written on the Liberation war, including Shamsur Rahman's famous poems written during the War. Arguably it is the most often used subject for Bangladeshi literature since 1971. The monuments made to commemorate the War are the highest esteemed monuments in Bangladesh.
==Films== * ''[[Stop Genocide]]'' – documentary by [[Zahir Raihan]] (1971) * ''Let There be Light'' by [[Zahir Raihan]] (1971) * ''Nine Months to Freedom: The Story of Bangladesh'' – documentary by S. Sukhdev (1972) * ''[[Ora Egaro Jon|11 Warriors]]'' (1972) by [[Chashi Nazrul Islam]] (1972) * ''Raktakto Bangla (The Blood-stained Bengal)'' by Mamtaj Ali (1972) * ''[[Dhire Bohe Meghna|Quiet Flows the river Meghna]]'' by Alamgir Kabir (1973)'' * ''Amar Jonmovumi'' (1973) * ''Ami Sadhinota Enechhi'' by [[Sagar Lohani]] (2003) * ''Shangram (Struggle)'', On the basis of [[Khaled Mosharraf]] Dairy, by [[Chashi Nazrul Islam]] (1973) * ''[[Arunodoyer Agnishakkhi]]'' (Witness of the Sun Rise) by ''[[Subhash Dutta]] ''(1974)'' * ''Megher Onek Rang (Clouds have Many Shades) by Harunur Rashid Mathin (1976)'' * ''Kolmilata by ''Shahidul alam Khan'' (1981)'' * ''Chitkar'' (1982) * ''Agami'' by [[Morshedul Islam]] (1984) * ''Hulia'' by [[Tanvir Mokammel]], On the basis of [[Nirmalendu Goon]]'s Hulia poem (1985) * ''Protyaborton'' (1986) * ''Suchona'' by [[Morshedul Islam]] (1988) * ''Charpotro'' (1988) * ''Bokhate'' (1989) * ''Duronto'' (1989) * ''Potaka'' (1989) * ''Nodir Naam Modhumoti'' by [[Tanvir Mokammel]] (1990) * ''Kalo Chil '71'' (1990) * ''Dushor Jatra'' (1992) * ''Ekattorer Jishu (Jesus '71)'' – feature film by [[Nasiruddin Yousuff]], based on [[Shahriar Kabir]]'s story (1993) * ''[[Muktir Gaan]] (Song of Freedom)'' (1995), ''[[Muktir Kotha|Story of Freedom]]'' (1999) and ''Narir Katha'' – three different [[Bengali language|Bengali]] documentaries by [[Tareque Masud]] and Catherine Masud * ''[[Aguner Poroshmoni]]'' – feature film by [[Humayun Ahmed]] (1995) * ''Ekhono Onek Raat'' (1997) * ''Hangar Nadi Granade'', On the basis of [[Selina Hossain]]'s novel, [[Chashi Nazrul Islam]] (1997) * ''Gourob'' (1998) * ''Chana O Muktijuddo'' (1998) * ''Ekattorer Lash'' (1998) * ''Itihas Kanna'' by Shamim AKter, Biography of a war child (1999) * ''Shovoner Ekattor'' (2000) * ''Muktijoddo O Jibon'' (2000) * ''Shei Rater Kotha Bolte Eshechi'' ("I Have Come to Speak of That Night") – documentary by Kawsar Chowdhury (2001) * ''Ekjon Muktijodda'' (2001) * ''Ekattorer Michil'' by [[Kabori Sarwar]] (2001) * ''Ekattorer Rong Pencil'' by Manan Hira (2001) * ''[[Matir Moina]]'' directed by [[Tareque Masud]], (2002) – winner of the FIPRESCI Prize at the 2002 [[Cannes Film Festival]]<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0319836/ Matir moina (The Clay Bird)]</ref> * ''Shilalipi'' by Shamim Akter, According to the Biography of [[Selina Parvin]] (2002) * ''Hridoyghata'' (2002) * ''Spartacus '71'' * ''Shorot '71'' by [[Morshedul Islam]] (2002) * ''[[Joyjatra|Journey to Victory]]'' – feature film by [[Tauquir Ahmed]], (2004) * ''[[Megher Pore Megh]]'' by [[Chashi Nazrul Islam]] (2004) * ''Dhrubotara'' (2006) * ''Swadinota'' by Yasmin Kabir (2006) * ''[[Shyamol Chhaya]]'' – feature film by [[Humayun Ahmed]], (2006) * ''Khelagor'' by [[Morshedul Islam]], (2006) * ''Asttitey Amar Desh'', According to the Biography of [[Matiur Rahman (military pilot)|Matiur Rahman]] directed by Khijir Hayat Khan (2007) * ''Nishongo Sarati'' (''Tajuddin Ahmad : An Unsung Hero'') by [[Tanvir Mokammel]], According to the Biography of [[Tajuddin Ahmad]] (2007) * ''Rabeya'' by [[Tanvir Mokammel]], (2009) * ''[[Meherjaan]]'' by Rubaiyat Hossain (2011) * ''[[Guerrilla (2011 film)|Guerrilla]]'' by [[Nasiruddin Yousuff]] (2011) * ''Khondo Golpo '71'' (2011) * ''[[Amar Bondhu Rashed]]'' by [[Morshedul Islam]] (2011) based on a juvenile novel by [[Muhammed Zafar Iqbal]] * ''[[Pita - The Father]]'' by Masud Akando (2012) * ''[[The War Crimes File]]'' by [[David Bergman (journalist)|David Bergman]] (Three men's role in Bangladesh war genocide) (2013) * ''[[Dateline Bangladesh]]'' by [[Gita Mehta]] (2013) * ''[[Nekabborer Mohaproyan]]'' directed by Masud Pathik, based on a poetry by [[Nirmalendu Goon]] (2014) * ''[[Shongram]]'' (2014) * ''[[Children of War (2014 film)|Children of War]]'' (2014) Indian [[Hindi]] film based on Bangladesh Liberation war * ''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n8P7uNqk5NQ Angels of Hell]'' by Shameem Shahid (2015); Short film based on war children of Bangladesh Liberation War * ''[[Bhuban Majhi]]'' by Fakhrul Arefeen Khan (2017)
==Plays== * ''Payer Awaj Pawa jay'' by [[Syed Shamsul Haque]] (1976) * ''Juddho Ebong Juddho'' by [[Syed Shamsul Haque]] (1986) * ''Joyjoyonti'' by [[Mamunur Rashid]] (1995) * ''Ekattorer Pala'' by Nasiruddin Yousuff Bacchu (1993) * ''Mukhosh'' * ''Kingsukh'' * J''e Merute'' * ''Bibisab'' by [[Abdullah al Mamun]] (1994) * ''Kotha '71'' * ''Bolod'' by [[Muhammed Zafar Iqbal]]
==Literature== * ''[[Ami Birangana Bolchi|Ami Virangana Balchhi]] (I am the Heroine of War, Speaking...)'' – memoir by [[Nilima Ibrahim]] * ''Ekatture Uttar Ronangaon ('71 Northern Front)'' – Factual War Accounts (in [[Bengali language|Bengali]]) by [[Muhammad Hamidullah Khan]], Sector Commander 11, War of Independence – [[Bangladesh]] * ''[[Amar Bondhu Rashed (book)|Amar Bondhu Rashed]] (My Friend Rashed)'' - Juvenile novel by [[Muhammed Zafar Iqbal]] * ''Ghum Nei (Sleepless Nights)'' – memoir by [[Nasiruddin Yusuf]] * ''Ami Bijoy Dekhechi (I have witnessed the Victory)'' – memoir by [[M. R. Akhtar Mukul]] * ''A Tale of Millions'' – memoir by Major (R) [[Rafik Ul Islam]] * ''Ekattorer Dinguli (Days of 71)'' – memoir by [[Jahanara Imam]] (1986) {{ISBN|984-480-000-5}} * ''[[Maa (Novel)|Maa]](The Mother)'' – novel by [[Anisul Hoque]] (2003) {{ISBN|984-458-422-1}} * ''Jochhna o Janani'r Galpo (The Tale of Moonlight and the Motherland)'' – novel by Humayun Ahmed (2004) {{ISBN|984-8682-76-7}} * ''Of Blood and Fire'' – * ''[[September on Jessore Road]]'' – poem by [[Allen Ginsberg]]<ref>[http://www.everyday-beat.org/ginsberg/poems/jessore.txt ''September on Jessore Road'']</ref> * ''[[A Golden Age]]'' – novel by [[Tahmima Anam]] * ''Aguner Poroshmoni'' - novel by [[Humayun Ahmed]] * ''1971'' - novel by [[Humayun Ahmed]] *''Of Martyrs and Marigolds'' - a novel written by a [[Stranded Pakistani]] woman, [[Aquila Ismail]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ismail|first1=Aquila|title=A Voice from Pakistan: Of Martyrs and Marigolds|url=http://www.peacexpeace.org/2012/08/a-voice-from-pakistan-of-martyrs-and-marigolds/|website=Peace X Peace|accessdate=3 January 2016}}</ref>
==Music== * ''[[The Concert for Bangladesh]]'', New York, 1971 * ''[[Song for Bangladesh]]'' – song by [[Joan Baez]]<ref>[http://www.joanbaez.com/Lyrics/bangladesh.html Lyrics]</ref> * ''[[Bangla Desh (song)|Bangla Desh]]'' – song by [[George Harrison]]
==Sculpture and Architecture== * [[Jatiyo Smriti Soudho]] (National Monument for Remembrance) in [[Savar]], [[Dhaka]] * [[Swadhinata Stambha]] (Independence Monument) in [[Suhrawardy Udyan]], Dhaka * [[Aparajeyo Bangla]] (Invincible Bengal) – sculpture in [[Dhaka University]] * [[Shabash Bangladesh]] (Bravo, Bangladesh) – sculpture in [[Rajshahi University]] * [[Shoparjito Shadhinota]] (Self Achieved Freedom) – sculpture in Dhaka University
==Museums== * [[Liberation War Museum]], Dhaka * Shahid Smriti Sangrohoshala (Martyr Memorial Museum), [[Rajshahi]]
==Digital Archive== * [[Muktijuddho e-Archive]]
==Videogames== * [[Amar Ei Desh]] * [[Arunodoyer Agnishikha]] * [[Liberation 71]] * [[Heroes of 71]] * [[Sector 71]]
== See also == * [[Artistic depictions of the Bengali Language Movement]] * [[Liberation War Museum]] * [[Muktijuddho e-Archive]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{External links|date=November 2015}}
'''Ayers Saint Gross, Architects and Planners''' is an architectural firm in [[Maryland]], U.S. specializing in master plans and building designs for [[higher education]] institutions.<ref name="ReferenceA">Walker, Childs. “Expansion of Baltimore architectural firm fueled by focus on colleges,” ''"Baltimore Sun"'', August 8, 2011</ref><ref name="Gunts, Edward 2000">Gunts, Edward. “Getting to be big firm on campus,” ''"Baltimore Sun"'', March 5, 2000.</ref> The firm is described as maintaining “a narrower focus on college and university work than any other in the country.” <ref>[http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/education/bs-md-architecture-college-ayers-20110808,0,6779005.story Walker, Childs. “Expansion of Baltimore architectural firm fueled by focus on colleges,” ''"Baltimore Sun"'', August 8, 2011 ]</ref>
Since the 1980s, Ayers Saint Gross has become a long-term adviser to universities including Harvard, Johns Hopkins and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The Firm’s academic projects range from [[campus]] master plans to classroom buildings, laboratories, performing arts centers and law and business schools.<ref name="Gunts, Edward 2000"/>
The firm employs about 130 professionals<ref name="ReferenceA"/> and is organized into studios specializing in planning, academic and student life facilities, landscape architecture, environmental signage and graphic design.<ref>[http://www.buildingarizona.org/tag/ayers-saint-gross%20 Mickelson, Kimberly. “Firm to Deliver Student Housing in Downtown Phoenix,” ''"Building Arizona"'', October 11, 2011]</ref>
Based in [[Baltimore]], the firm was known for institutional and residential projects until the 1980s when it specialized in the "design and planning for non-profit institutions, with a specific focus on higher education." The current president is Luanne Greene, FAIA, LEED AP.<ref name="ASG">asg-architwects.com/firm/people/</ref>
==History== Ayers Saint Gross is the successor firm to '''Sill, Buckler & Fenhagen''', founded in 1912 and known as the designer of [[Baltimore City College|The Baltimore City College]], the third oldest public high school in America, founded downtown in 1839, and having occupied eight different locations in its now 175-year-old history. Some of the City College's earlier buildings were landmark structures in their era, built by several famous local architects of the time. "Buckler & Fenhagen" won the national competition in the 1920s with their design for BCC's landmark stone [[Gothic Revival architecture|Collegiate Gothic]] "Castle on the Hill" on the highest hilltop in the northeast section of the City overlooking the downtown skyline to the south. Built at a cost of over 2.4 million dollars, during 1924-1928, the "Castle" still serves this magnet, college prep high school which focuses on the humanities, liberal arts, social studies and the Classics and is traditionally one of the best performing student body in the State. As a humorous note, carved limestone faces of both architects are placed as small stone "[[gargoyles]]" on either side of a large central window over the front entrance. School website: (http://www.baltimorecitycollege.us), and http://www.cityforever.org), [http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-03-05/entertainment/0003050317_1_ayers-saint-gross-colleges-and-universities-baltimore-city-college%20 Gunts, Edward. “Getting to be big firm on campus,” ''"[[Baltimore Sun]]"'', March 5, 2000. ]''"[[Baltimore Sun]]"''
In 1938, the original partners hired Richard “Dick” Ayers whose employment was interrupted by [[World War II]] when he served in the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] and toured [[Japan]] as a member of the "Strategic Bombing Survey".<ref>Rasmussen, Fred. “Richard Winston Ayers, architect,” Baltimore Sun, April 4, 1995</ref> Ayers returned to Buckler and Fenhagen after the War and in 1955, he and Julius Meyer took over the Firm. They were joined later by Kelsey Saint, a [[Yale University|Yale]] classmate, and the partners went on to design [[Homewood Campus of Johns Hopkins University|Shriver Hall]], the Newton White Athletic Center and the [[Milton S. Eisenhower Library]] on the "[[Homewood Campus of Johns Hopkins University|Homewood]]" campus of [[Johns Hopkins University|The Johns Hopkins University]].<ref>Kelly, Jacques. “Kelsey Y. Saint, 93, noted architect,” ''"Baltimore Sun"'', June 6, 2006.</ref> In 1984, Adam Gross was also recruited to the Firm. Under his leadership, "Ayers Saint Gross" became one of the most honored design studios in Maryland. [http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-03-05/entertainment/0003050317_1_ayers-saint-gross-colleges-and-universities-baltimore-city-college%20 Gunts, Edward. “Getting to be big firm on campus,” ''"Baltimore Sun"'', March 5, 2000. ]
Gross and principal Jim Wheeler, who joined the firm in 1987, [http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-14521321/40-under-40-forty.html Gainor, Cathy. “40 under 40,” Baltimore Business Journal, September 17, 1993] repositioned the firm to focus on college and university work. They based this shift on the growing need for campus design expertise in response to the children of "baby boomers" flooding higher education. [http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/education/bs-md-architecture-college-ayers-20110808,0,6779005.story Walker, Childs. “Expansion of Baltimore architectural firm fueled by focus on colleges,” ''"Baltimore Sun"'', August 8, 2011 ]<ref name="Gunts, Edward 2000"/> That strategy led to the firm’s rapid growth.<ref name="Gunts, Edward 2000"/>
The firm opened offices in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], [[Tempe, Arizona]], and [[Washington, D.C.]]<http://www.asg-architects.com/firm/contact> as a result of various work projects for universities in those locations. [http://www.bizjournals.com/baltimore/stories/2004/07/19/daily25.html%20 Harlan, Heather. “Ayers/Saint/Gross opens Phoenix office,” ''"Baltimore Business Journal"'', July 21, 2004] . Today, the Baltimore office of "Ayers Saint Gross" is headquartered in an old [[Procter and Gamble]] soap-making factory, renovated into an office park named "Tide Point" on the southside of the City’s "[[Inner Harbor]]".<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="Gunts, Edward 2000"/>
==Work== Projects include the new [[National Library for George Washington]] at [[Mount Vernon]], near [[Alexandria, Virginia|Alexandria]], [[Virginia]],<ref>Trescott, Jacqueline. “Mount Vernon to add presidential library and scholars guesthouse,” ''"Washington Post"'', April 14, 2011</ref> the master plan for the re-use of the historic [[St. Elizabeths Hospital]] campus in [[Washington, D.C.]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120326212505/http://www.stelizabethseast.com/document-center/ D.C. Department of Transportation and D.C. Office of Planning] [http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/print-edition/2011/07/01/st-elizabeths-project-wins-some.html Krouse, Sarah. “St. Elizabeths project wins some, loses some,” ''"Washington Business Journal"'', July 1, 2011 ] and master plans for [[Virginia Commonwealth University]], [https://archive.is/20130204131736/http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/2011/nov/11/tdmet03-vcu-begins-work-on-new-master-plan-ar-1451455/ Kapsidelis, Karin. “VCU begins work on new master plan,” November 11, 2011.] the [[University of Southern California]] health sciences campus, [https://web.archive.org/web/20100621155337/http://theweekly.usc.edu/detail.php?recordnum=16894 Fried, Ina. “Looking ahead to 2035, USC maps out plan for campus,” ''"The USC Weekly"'', March 5, 2010] and new campuses in Asia.<ref>[http://baltimorerealestate.citybizlist.com/1/2012/3/15/Johns-Hopkins-Ayers-Saint-Gross-JLL-Developing-3M-SF-Medical-Campus-in-Malaysia.aspx Johns Hopkins, Ayers Saint Gross, JLL Developing 3M SF Medical Campus in Malaysia,” ''"Citybiz Real Estate"'', March 15, 2012]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Sustainable design== In 2011, "Ayers Saint Gross" was ranked by ''"Engineering News Record"'' as 33 out of the "Top 100 Green Design Firms". [http://enr.construction.com/toplists/GreenDesignFirms/001-100.asp Engineering News Record] Its projects are designed to meet standards set by the U.S. Green Building Council under its "Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design", (LEED) program. About 70 percent of the firm’s architects are LEED-accredited. [http://landscapeonline.com/research/article/ Landscape Online] "Ayers Saint Gross" designs to LEED Silver standards and has exceeded this rating on some projects, such as the Thomas Jefferson Visitors Center at "[[Monticello]]". [http://www.thomasjeffersonfoundation.com/pressroom/showArticle.php?id=290 Thomas Jefferson Foundation]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} At [[Emory University]], the architects have designed several freshman residence halls to make use of rainwater harvesting and condensation reclamation. [http://chronicle.com/blogs/buildings/new-buildings-at-emory-ufurman-u-use-innovative-technology-for-sustainability/5174 Carlson, Scott. “New Buildings at Emory U. and Furman U. Use Innovative Technology for Sustainability.” ''"Chronicle of Higher Education"''. May 23, 2008 ] [http://www.architectmagazine.com/education-projects/come-rain-or-shine.aspx?printerfriendly=true King, W. Scott, “Come Rain or Shine,” ''"Architect"'' magazine, September 2008. ] The firm has recently designed the John and Frances Angelos Law Center for the [[University of Baltimore]], undertaken in partnership with Behnisch Architekten of [[Stuttgart, Germany|Stuttgart]] in [[Germany]], to be the first completely LEED Platinum-certified law school building in the United States. [http://baltimorerealestate.citybizlist.com/1/2012/2/15/Angelos-Law-Center-Set-to-be-First-LEED-Platinum-Law-School-Building-in-U.S.aspx CityBiz Real Estate, February 15, 2012 ]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
==Notable plans and buildings== *Bloomberg Center for Physics and Astronomy, [[Johns Hopkins University]], Baltimore, Maryland, 1990<ref>Yee, Roger. Educational Environments, Visual Reference Publications, Inc., 2002</ref> *[[Johns Hopkins University]] "Campus Master Plan", Baltimore, Maryland, 2000 [http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/education/bs-md-architecture-college-ayers-20110808,0,6779005.story Walker, Childs. “Expansion of Baltimore architectural firm fueled by focus on colleges,” ''"Baltimore Sun"'', August 8, 2011 ] *Darden Graduate School of Business Administration, [[University of Virginia]], Charlottesville, Virginia, 2002 [http://www.bluffton.edu/~sullivanm/virginia/charlottesville/uvadarden/darden3.html “Darden Graduate School of Business Administration,” 2002] *[[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], "Campus Master Plan", Chapel Hill, North Carolina, 2006<ref name="ReferenceA"/> *School of Nursing, [[Duke University]], Durham, North Carolina, 2007 [http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2007-12-01/business/0712010051_1_baltimore-office-public-relations-relations-and-marketing] *Rutgers School of Law-Camden, Camden, NJ, 2008 [[Rutgers School of Law–Camden|Camden @ Rutgers School of Law]] *[[Harvard University]] Allston Campus, Boston, Massachusetts, 2008 [http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2008/10/23/harvard-shows-revised-allston-plan-to/ Ni, Nan and Viswanathan, Vidya B., “Harvard Shows Revised Allston Plan to Residents,” The Harvard Crimson, October 23, 2008.] *[[Wilmer Eye Institute]], [[Johns Hopkins University]], Baltimore, Maryland, 2009 [http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2009-06-09/business/0906080083_1_hopkins-east-baltimore-campus-wilmer-eye-institute-wilmer-building Gunts, Edward. “New Wilmer Building Boosts Eye Research,” ''"Baltimore Sun"'', June 9, 2009] *[[Thomas Jefferson Visitors Center]] & Smith Education Center, "[[Monticello]]", Charlottesville, Virginia, 2009 [http://business.highbeam.com/409663/article-1G1-197669987/monticellos-new-visitor-center Dietsch, Deborah K. “Monticello’s New Visitor Center,” ''"Washington Times"'', April 12, 2009] *[https://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2009/04/10/arts/20090410-monticello-slideshow_3.html Rothstein, Edward. “Jefferson’s Blind Spots and Ideals, in Brick and Mortar,” ''[[The New York Times]]'', April 9, 2009.] *Art and Design Building, [[George Mason University]], Fairfax, Virginia, 2010 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140106161821/http://www.fairfaxcounty.gov/dpz/designawards/2010/ http://www.fairfaxcounty.gov/dpz/designawards/2010/ ] *Freshman residence halls at [[Emory University]], Atlanta, Georgia, 2007-2014 [http://chronicle.com/blogs/buildings/new-buildings-at-emory-ufurman-u-use-innovative-technology-for-sustainability/5174 Carlson, Scott. “New Buildings at Emory U. and Furman U. Use Innovative Technology for Sustainability.” *''"Chronicle of Higher Education"''. May 23, 2008 ] [http://www.architectmagazine.com/education-projects/come-rain-or-shine.aspx?printerfriendly=true King, W. Scott, “Come Rain or Shine,” ''"Architect"'' magazine, September 2008. ]

revision.text:
[[Image:Birmingham back-to-backs.jpg|right|thumb|Birmingham Back to Backs on [[Hurst Street]]]] '''Birmingham Conservation Trust''' is a charity which saves and restores historic buildings in the city of [[Birmingham]], [[England]]. In 2004 it completed the conservation and restoration of the last surviving court of [[Birmingham Back to Backs|Back to Back houses]] on [[Hurst Street]] in the city. These are now run by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]].
[[Image:Perrotts Folly Crop.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Perrott's Folly<ref name="BCT">{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghamconservationtrust.org/bct-finished/perrotts-folly/|title=Perrott’s Folly|publisher=Birmingham Conservation Trust|accessdate=22 November 2009}}</ref>]] Birmingham Conservation Trust moved on to a short term project managing the protection of [[Perrott's Folly]] — a tower in the city which has close associations with [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]. Work has been taking place to ensure the tower does not collapse.
Another project is Newman Brothers, a family-run factory in Birmingham's unique [[Jewellery Quarter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/newman-brothers-coffin-works-jewellery-5380940|title=Newman Brothers Coffin Works in Jewellery Quarter brought back from the dead - Birmingham Mail|author=Jane Tyler|work=birminghammail}}</ref> The firm made some of the world's finest [[coffin]] furniture, including the fittings for the funerals of [[Winston Churchill]], [[Joseph Chamberlain]] and [[Diana, Princess of Wales]]. The very last sets of cast brass gothic handles from this factory were used on the coffins of Cardinal [[Basil Hume]] and of [[Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother]].
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.birminghamconservationtrust.org Birmingham Conservation Trust] *[https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/birmingham-back-to-backs Birmingham Back to Backs at National Trust] *{{EW charity|1063124}}
[[Category:Community organisations in Birmingham, West Midlands|Conservation Trust]] [[Category:Conservation and restoration organizations]] [[Category:Charities based in Birmingham, West Midlands]]

page.title: Carolingian Gospel Book (British Library, MS Add. 11848)

revision.text:
[[File:Minuscule caroline.jpg|thumb|250px|This Carolingian Gospel Book is written in a fine [[Carolingian minuscule]].]]
'''British Library, Additional Manuscript 11848''' is an [[Illuminated manuscript|illuminated]] [[Carolingian]] [[Latin]] [[Gospel Book]] produced at [[Tours]]. It contains the [[Vulgate]] translation of the four [[Gospel]]s written on [[vellum]] in [[Carolingian minuscule]] with [[Square Capitals|Square]] and [[Rustic Capitals]] and [[Uncial]]s as display scripts. The manuscript has 219 extant [[Bookbinding|folio]]s which measure approximately 330 by 230 mm. The text is written in area of about 205 by 127 mm. In addition to the text of the Gospels, the manuscript contains the letter of [[St. Jerome]] to [[Pope Damasus I|Pope Damasus]] and of [[Eusebius of Caesarea]] to [[Carpian]], along with the Eusebian [[canon tables]]. There are prologues and capitula lists before each Gospel. A table of readings for the year was added, probably between 1675 and 1749, to the end of the volume. This is followed by a list of capitula incipits and a word grid which were added in the Carolingian period.
== Provenance ==
The [[codex]] was produced at the Monastery of [[Martin of Tours|St. Martin at Tours]] between 820 and 830, under the abbacy [[Fridugisus]], who was the successor of [[Alcuin]]. It is the earliest known Gospel Book from Tours to contain four [[Evangelist portrait]]s. The location of the book is uncertain until the 18th century. There is a book stamp on folio 1 that indicates that the volume belonged to Count Suchtelan, the Russian Ambassador to Stockholm in the 18th century. In the early 19th century it belonged to Lord Strangford. It was sold at Sotheby's in August 1831 and was purchased by [[Samuel Butler (schoolmaster)|Samuel Butler]], Bishop of Lichfield. The [[British Library]] acquired the book along with the rest of Bishop Butler's collection of manuscripts.
== Decorations ==
[[Image:BritLibAddMS11848Fol109vLuke.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Folio 109 verso contains a portrait of the Evangelist [[Luke the Evangelist|Luke]].]]
The manuscript contains canon tables set within architectural arcades which are decorated with zoomorphic and foliate designs. There are four Evangelist portraits. Each evangelist is shown as a scribe and is identified by a half-length symbol above him and by an inscription. The portraits show some similarities to some [[Insular art|Insular]] manuscripts and some Court School manuscripts, as might be expected given the nationality Fridugisus, who was English, and from his connections to the Carolingian court. The portraits have been described as being "coarsely executed". The manuscript also contains a decorated title page and incipit page for each gospel. There are also decorated major and minor initials. The major initials are done in early [[Franco-Saxon]] style and were done by a different artist than the one who did the portraits.
== Binding == The volume still has its Carolingian [[treasure binding]] dating from the ninth century. The covers were refurbished in the 14th and 19th centuries. The covers are oak panels covered in embossed silver. The front cover has the figure of a seated Christ in Majesty enclosed within a rectangular frame decorated with stones and foliate designs. The majority of the medal work is 9th century typical of mid-ninth century Carolingian metalwork. In the four corners of the frame are enamels of the four evangelist symbols, which were added in the fourteenth century. The enamels were probably produced at [[Limoges]]. The original colored stones were replaced by jewels in 1838 for Bishop Butler. There are [[relic]]s of finger bones from an anonymous saint embedded on the interior of the boards. The clasps for the volume were probably replaced in the 19th century.
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040618171434/http://www.bl.uk/catalogues/manuscripts/HITS0001.ASP?VPath=c%21%2Finetpub%2Fwwwroot%2Fmss%2Fdata%2Fmsscat%2Fhtml%2F9989.htm&Search=11848&Highlight=F British Library catalogue entry]
== Further reading == *''[[Monumenta Germaniae Historica]]. Poeta Latini Aevi Karolini'', Volume IV, p. 928. *''Catalogue of Ancient Manuscripts, Volume II, Latin'', pp. 26-28. *Rand, E.K. ''A Survey of the Manuscripts of Tours, Medieval Academy of America Publications, no. 3, Studies in the Script of Tours'', I (1929), no. 78. *Koehler, W. ''Die Karolingischen Miniaturen, I, Die Schule von Tours'' (1930), no. 19. *Hubert, J., Porcher, J. and Volbach, W.F. ''Carolingian Art'' (London, 1970), pp.126-128, 350, pls 114-115. *Garrison, M., Nelson, J.L. and [[Dominic Tweddle|Tweddle, D.]] ''Alcuin and Charlemagne. The Golden Age of York'' (York, 2001), no. 55.
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051110131046/http://prodigi.bl.uk/Illimages/iBase/components/228/22849_2.jpg Image of top cover board.] *[https://archive.is/20030329220441/http://www.humanities.uci.edu/spanishandportuguese/spanish/medievaliberia/manuscript_glossary_C-D.html Carolingian manuscripts]: a brief introduction
